awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Development and Applications of Photocontrolled Cationic Polymerizations
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Brett P. Fors of Cornell University is supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) program of the Division of Chemistry to develop new synthetic methods for the preparation of polymers with control over chemical structures and properties.  This approach takes advantage of interesting characteristics of visible light to enable the synthesis of previously inaccessible polymer architectures. The properties of polymeric materials are directly controlled by chemical structure and the methods developed in this project enable the synthesis and utilization of improved polymeric materials for applications in adhesives, elastomers, and electronics. Educational activities are integrated into this project.  The focus of these activities is on the development of a polymer science summer camp that exposes Native American students to Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) education and research at an early age. The objective is to stimulate the interest of Native American students in STEM related fields.

The project develops a cationic polymerization process for vinyl ethers that is regulated by visible light through the reversible oxidation of a polymer chain end with a photocatalyst.  Precise spatial and temporal control over polymer chain growth is achieved by the photoinitiated reversible formation of a propagating cation.  This cationic polymerization process is being used in combination with other photocontrolled radical polymerization processes to enable switching between different polymerization mechanisms. Monomer selectivity in situ is achieved by modulating the wavelength of irradiation. This protocol provides control over polymer sequence with an external stimulus and allows the synthesis of previously inaccessible polymer structures. Additionally, similar strategies are being developed for photocontrolled polymerization of epoxides, thus extending the scope and expanding the practicality of this approach. Synthetic polymers are of importance in all aspects of modern life and have facilitated major societal advances. Innovative synthetic methods are required to enable the synthesis of complex materials with unknown function. Photocontrolled cationic processes allow for the development of new polymeric structures with previously inaccessible architectures. Importantly, high levels of spatial and temporal control gained in photocontrolled polymerizations facilitate the application of these new methods in fields such as lithography, coatings, and biology. This award enables the establishment of a polymer science camp on the Flathead Indian Reservation in collaboration with the Salish and Kootenai College. This summer camp introduces Native American students to research activities at an early age in order to increase their interest and participation in STEM fields. Additionally, through workshops for teachers on the Flathead Indian Reservation the quality of STEM related education increases for elementary and middle school Native American students. These efforts contribute to creating a diverse STEM workforce in the United States.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Work during this grant period led to 10 publications and trained multiple graduate and undergraduate students.  Below, we highlight the results from this funding period.

Stimuli-controlled cationic polymerizations of vinyl ethers. Intellectual Merit: Synthetic methods regulated by an external stimulus have the capacity to afford polymers with precisely controlled architectures and functions. To this end, during the last funding period we are developed new strategies in which photochemistry and electrochemistry provide control over monomer sequence in a polymer backbone—sequence-controlled polymerizations are regarded as a “holy grail’ in polymer science. Specifically, we developed methods where we can control the cationic polymerization of vinyl ethers using an electrochemical, photochemical or chemical stimulus and can reversibly switch to a radical polymerization of acrylates using a photochemical stimulus. This new system allowed us to temporally dictate when a monomer is added to a polymer chain end to control the formation of block polymers. Importantly, the length of each segment is dictated by the amount of time the individual stimulus is applied and the total number of blocks is controlled by the number of times we switch between the two stimuli. Broader Impacts: These methods allow us to have unprecedented control over polymer structure to enable precise control over material function. For example, we have successfully applied these photoswitchable polymerizations to 3D printing where we can spatiotemporally control cross-linking density to provide materials with precisely defined physical properties on the macro and micro scale. We believe these methods will allow the scientific community to access to polymer structures and functions.

Development of User-Friendly Controlled Cationic Polymerizations Under Ambient. Intellectual Merit: In our work on developing stimuli-controlled polymerizations, we realized that the sensitivity of these cationic polymerizations was a limiting factor in the practicality of these processes. Specifically, controlled cationic polymerizations require cryogenic temperatures, highly inert atmospheres, and rigorously purified monomers, solvents, and catalysts. Taking advantage of the unique reactivity of pentacarboxycyclopentadienes (PCCPs), we developed a new strategy for the controlled cationic polymerization of vinyl ethers under ambient conditions. Critically, these polymerizations can be run open to the air, at room temperature, and with unpurified monomer. Broader Impacts: The broader impacts of this work are significant as the ability to conduct cationic polymerizations under user-friendly conditions will open up these processes to non-specialists for use in a wide variety of applications and also makes these polymerizations more practical on an industrial scale.

Reversible Redox Controlled Acids for Cationic Ring-Opening Polymerizations. Intellectual Merit: We wanted to extend the scope of stimuli-controlled cationic polymerizations beyond vinyl ethers and set out to develop electrochemically switchable acids.  We synthesized a variety of phosphoric acids that were redox active and showed that through electrochemical oxidation we could reversibly change the acidity of these acids by up to four orders of magnitude. We applied these acids to the ring-opening polymerizations of lactones where we could temporally control chain growth by either oxidizing or reducing the acid in an electrochemical cell.  Broader Impacts:  This work lays the groundwork for a new class of switchable polymerizations but also provides a new activation mode for switchable acids that we believe will find use in a number of applications beyond the ring-opening polymerization of lactones.  We believe this new class of electrochemically switchable acids will be useful in a number of fields across science and engineering.

 

Educational Outreach. Over 50 million students in the United States had schools that closed to slow the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic. These closings resulted in significant loss of educational achievement when compared to the average in-person classroom environment; however, this gap was reduced by up to 50% with higher quality remote learning. 

In the midst of the COVID-19 school shutdowns, our lab saw this as an opportunity to broadly influence science education and began developing polymer science labs for remote learners. Importantly, labs enable students to engage in practical learning opportunities despite being remote. We developed an experiment that uses household items in order to teach polymer chemistry concepts including tensile strength, crosslinking density, and sustainable polymer synthesis, and we included activity sheets appropriate for both middle schoolers and high schoolers to help reinforce learning goals. We presented these virtual labs to over a dozen middles school and high school teachers from across the US and received excellent feedback—several of these teachers have already used our polymer-based laboratory in their online learning environments. 


Last Modified: 05/25/2023
Modified by: Brett P Fors
